case_vignette:
A 12-year-old healthy male presents for evaluation of rash on the chest and back ongoing for the past 4 days. Mother reports that she first noticed a larger spot on his right flank, then smaller similar lesions began developing all over the chest and back. She denies any history of eczema for the patient or family history. She denies any new topical products. The rash is not painful or itchy. Mother has tried topical over the counter hydrocortisone without any improvement. Physical examination is remarkable for erythematous pink thin papules and plaqueswith overlying fine thin scale on the back and chest. A larger thin scaly plaque is appreciated on the right flank. A KOH preparation is performed and does not reveal any fungal elements  The patient is a 12-year-old healthy female who presents for evaluation of rash on the chest and back ongoing for the past 4 days. Mother reports that she first noticed a larger spot on her daughter's right flank, then smaller similar lesions began developing all over the chest and back. She denies any history of eczema for the patient or family history. She denies any new topical products. The rash is not painful or itchy. Mother has tried topical over the counter hydrocortisone without any improvement. Physical examination is remarkable for erythematous pink thin papules and plaques with overlying fine thin scale on the back and chest. A larger thin scaly plaque is appreciated on the right flank. A KOH preparation is performed and does not reveal any fungal elements. 

Note: I've swapped the pronouns and nouns to make the text grammatically correct. I've also swapped the gender-specific adjectives (e.g. "healthy male" becomes "healthy female"). Let me know if you have any further requests!

Mother reports that she first noticed a larger spot on her daughter's right flank, then smaller similar lesions began developing all over the chest and back. She denies any history of eczema for the patient or family history. She denies any new topical products. The rash is not painful or itchy. Mother has tried topical over the counter hydrocortisone without any improvement. Physical examination is remarkable for erythematous pink thin papules and plaques with overlying fine thin scale

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a rash on my chest and back that started 4 days ago.
Can you describe the appearance of the rash?
The rash consists of pink, thin papules and plaques with a fine, thin scale on my chest and back, and there is a larger scaly plaque on my right flank.
Have you experienced any recent illnesses, like a sore throat or a cold, prior to the rash appearing?
No, I have not experienced any recent illnesses before the rash appeared.
Do you have a history of any skin conditions or allergies?
No, I don't have a history of any skin conditions or allergies.
Has anyone in your family had a similar rash or any other chronic skin conditions?
No, there is no family history of similar rashes or chronic skin conditions.
Is the rash itchy or painful?
The rash is not painful or itchy.
Final Diagnosis: Pityriasis Rosea
